### Problem 0

```{r}
library(tidyverse)
```

### Problem 1
```{r clean_538_plots}
month_df = tibble(
    month_num = 1:12,
    month_abb = month.abb,
    month = month.name
  )
 
pols = 
  read_csv("data/pols-month.csv") |> 
  separate(mon, into = c("year", "month_num", "day"), convert = TRUE) |> 
  mutate(president = recode(prez_gop, "0" = "dem","1" = "gop", "2" ="gop" )) |>
  left_join(x = _, y = month_df) |> 
  select(year, month, everything(), -day, -starts_with("prez"))
  
  
```

We also clean the 538 `snp` data, which contains information related to Standard & Poorâ€™s stock market index.

```{r clean_538_snp}
snp = 
  read_csv("data/snp.csv") |> 
  separate(date, into = c("month", "day", "year"), convert = TRUE) |> 
  arrange(year, month) |> 
  mutate(month = month.name[month]) |>
  select(year, month, close)
  
```

we tidy the `unemployment` data so that it can be merged with the `pols` and `snp` datasets.
```{r clean_538_unemp}
unemployment = 
  read_csv("data/unemployment.csv") |>
  rename(year = Year) |>
  pivot_longer(
    Jan:Dec,
    names_to = "month_abb",
    values_to = "unemployment") |> 
  left_join(x = _, y = month_df) |> 
  select(year, month, unemployment)
  
```

we merge the three datasets

```{r merge_538}
data_problem1 =
  left_join(pols, snp) |> 
  left_join(x = _, y = unemployment)

str(data_problem1)
```
There are some `NA` values in the `close` and `unemployment` variables, which indicate that the value of these variables are missing at those locations.

In the 538 datasets, the `pols` data has `r ncol(pols)` variables and `r nrow(pols)` observations.

### Problme 3 
```{r}
baseline_data =
  read_csv("data/data_mci/MCI_baseline.csv", skip = 1) |> 
  janitor::clean_names() |> 
  mutate(
    sex = 
      case_match(
        sex, 
        1 ~ "male", 
        0 ~ "female"),
    sex = as.factor(sex),
    apoe4 = 
      case_match(
        apoe4,
        1 ~ "apoe4_carrier",
        0 ~ "apoe4_non_carrier"),
      apoe4 = as.factor(apoe4))
  
     
  


```

##questions
```{r}
mci_baseline_participant = 
  mutate( 
    baseline_data,
    age_at_onset = 
      ifelse(age_at_onset == ".", NA, age_at_onset)
     )|> 
      filter(current_age < age_at_onset| is.na(age_at_onset))

  
  
```

```{r}
mci_develop =
  mci_baseline_participant |> 
  filter(!(current_age > age_at_onset |is.na(age_at_onset)))
```

According to the Baseline dataset, we could see that there have `r nrow (mci_baseline_participant)` participants were recruited. And based on the current age and age on set, we found `r mci_baseline_participant |> filter(current_age < age_at_onset) |> nrow()` develop MCI. And the average baseline age is `r baseline_data |> pull(current_age) |> mean() |> round(2)`years old. In the dataset, we found that `r filter(baseline_data, sex == "female", apoe4 =="apoe4_carrier") |> nrow()/nrow(filter(mci_baseline_participant, sex == "female")) *100`% women in the study are APOE4 carriers.

```{r}
  )
  
  

```


```{r}
mci_all = 
  inner_join(
    mci_develop, amyloid_data, by = "id"
  )
```

According to the two datasets, we found that there are  `r mci_all |> distinct(id) |> nrow()` participants appear in both datasets.
